epartment building erected about 1911.  About 1923.

722297f-b.text:
Park Avenue, west side, north from E. 60th St., showing mainly the demolition of No. 520, an apartment building at the N. W. corner. This was erected in 1911, and is to be replaced by the new Christ Church, N. E.

The photographer's vantage point for the extensive view is E. 59th Street.

View 2 is of earlier date and includes the apartment building at the S. W. corner of 61st Street. This came down prior to No. 520 and the site remained vacant for years. The N. Y. Times of January 16, 1940 reports the proposed improvement of this location with a modern 19 story apartment building.

View 3 is westward on 60th St. during demolition of No. 520. The Hotel Pierre appears to the left.

View 1- October 21, 1930
View 2- September 11, 1928
View 3- October 21, 1930

P. L. Sperr

722291f-b.text:
Park Avenue, at East 60th Street, showing two corners of same as viered eastward on the street and across the Avenue. The cleared site will be improved with the new Chriat Church. The apartment building hown is No. 521 Park (erected 1911) and is at the N.W. corner. The Grolier Socfety Clubhouse is
at the left, tho darkly shown.
December 21, 1930
P. L. Srerr

722299f-b.text:
Park Avenue, west side, from East 60th (left) to 6lst (right) Streets, showing an entire blockfront clearance. The photographer is viewfng generally westward towards 5th Ave. and where (in Views 1&2) appear the Hotels Savoy Plaza and the Sherry Netherland. View 3 shows the southeasterly
side of the Grolter Society Club building.
Chrit Church (M. E.) will rise at the southerly Palf of this site and the balcnce will not be erected upon
until 1940. For further data see other views.
Tecember 21, 1930
Views 1,2,3
P. L. Sperr

722303f-b.text:
Park Avenue, at East 6lst Street as viewed northeastward from atop the Grolier Society Clubhouse (47-49 E.6D Street) and across the cleared Brearley School site (S. W. corner of 6lst Street) to show mainly the 15 and 12 story apartment houses thst are respectively, No's. 535 8555 Park Avenue. These occupy the east frontage, from 61st to 62nd
Streets.
View No.1 emphasizes tho 12 story building (No. 540) at the N. W. corner of 61st Street and is photographed from
the same point of vantage.
May 13, 1930
Views 1,2,3
P. L. Sperr

722290f-a.text:
Park Avenue, west side, north from East 80th St., showing the cleared 60th-6lst Street frontage and apartment buildings north of same. The prominent 12 story white structure is No. 540 Park Avenue (erected 1908) and is at the N. W. corner of E. 61st Street. Adjotning to the north is the 17 story anartment building, No. 550 Park Ave., a structure over shadowing the Colonial facaded Colony Club.
December 21, 1930
Views 1,2
. L. Sperr

Park Avenue, west side, north from East 80th St., showing the cleared 60th-6lst Street frontage and apartment buildings north of same. The prominent 12 story white structure is No. 540 Park Avenue (erected 1908) and is at the N. W. corner of E. 61st Street. Adjotning to the north is the 17 story anartment building, No. 550 Park Ave., a structure over shadowing the Colonial facaded Colony Club.

Views 1,2

722295f-a.text:
Park Ave., east side, south from, but not including East 60th Street.
Prominent building shown, is the Rits Tower.
June 11, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.

722298f-a.text:
Pnrk Avenue, west side, from E. 60th to 6lst Streets, showing Christ Church (M. E. ) and the Park Avenue Tennis Club. The church, a new edifice of the congregation of the Madison Avenue M. E. Church is at the N. W. corner of 60th Street and replaced an apartment house (erected in 1911 and demolished in 1930). The tennis courts are where the Brearley School formerly stood (also cleared in 1930). Upon this site (N. Y. Times of Jan. 18, 1940) will rise a 19 story apartment house. Note the Savoy Plaza Hotel
in the center background.
Aukust 13, 1936
P. L. Sperr

722296f-a.text:
Park Ave., at the N.W. corner of East 60th Street, showing Christ Church (new edifice for the former Madison Ave. M.E. Church which stood at the
N.E. corner of Madison Ave. and East 60th Street).
August 4, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
